dialogues.text: Make sure they're in bed before  midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinking) Before midnight? Then should I wake  them up for the countdown to the New  Year?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wife looks disgusted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Man and Wife exit, he turns to the kids and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't misbehave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man and Wife book it down the hall before Ted can change mind.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 716
dialogues.text: Ted is standing facing the door the Man and Wife just  disappeared through. He turns around slowly to face the  children. His eyes are wide. His face is quiet. Stern. The children are staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. These are the rules. Don't  break the rules and I won't break  your necks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) I always wanted to say that. Someone  said that to me when I was a kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah laughs at his joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except they were joking. I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rules are simple. Don't do  anything you wouldn't do if your  parents were here. If there's an  emergency, call me on the phone,  like your dad said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what he said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's surprised by a challenge this early in the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to call if we need anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've got a lot of work to do  and I can't have you calling me every  time you want a drink of water, so  please limit your calls to emergencies  only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We paid you five hundred dollars.  We'll call you if we need anything.  You don't want to upset my dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Please. Try to call only when  necessary. Watch TV, and if you're  good, I'll bring up some milk and  cookies. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted walks briskly down the hall, counting his money the w way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho takes off his socks and shoes and throws them ont the floor. Sarah looks at the discarded shoes and socks. CLOSE ON the shoes and socks. Sarah looks over at Juancho's bare feet. Her nose twitche

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your feet stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho smells his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah throws his shoes and socks behind her. They land on the bed. Juancho is flipping channels and finds an interesting sho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it out. T & A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah realizes he found a Nudie station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change it. You're not supposed to  watch this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not this kind of TV. Change it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho rolls up in a ball, the remote tucked in some rec of his stomach. Sarah hits him, then goes to the phone. She punches 0, si on the bed, and checks the name on the name tag pinned to her shirt.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK
dialogues.text: Ted walks up to the front desk just as the phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Front desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah is taking off her white winter tights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted? Hi. It's me, Sarah. You're our  sitter for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus, what did I tell you? I  said if you don't bother me, you'll  get milk and cookies. Now, do you  want them or do you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to turn off the Nudie  station in our room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted checks the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading stats on  room 716) I can't turn on an adult station  without permission from your parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. (struggling with winter  tights) Not turn it on, turn it off. It's  already on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what the machine tells  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, stop listening to the machine  and listen to me. There's naked ladies  dancing on my TV and I want 'em off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're good, you'll get milk and  cookies, so leave me alone, please.  I'll be up later to put you both to  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 716
dialogues.text: Angry, Sarah slams down the phone. She has an unusually a temper. We know where she gets it from. She looks up and  sees that the nudies are still in full force.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Change the channel, now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho turns around. He has a face like someone just lai fart in his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you're the one with the stinky  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah smells her feet. Twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't stink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, smell for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sticks her foot out for Juancho to smell. He's reluct Fearful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slowly, very slowly... climbs onto the bed and lowers head to her foot. Very slowly. Sarah waits until he's close enough to her foot before sh kicks him in the face, sending him somersaulting off the and crashing to the floor. She grabs the remote control he left behind and changes t channel to a cartoon. Juancho gets up and realizes his defeat. He decides to wa about. Looking for something to do... Sarah tries to ignore him as he stalks the room. It's onl matter of time before he finds mischief. Juancho sees the champagne bucket and Bingo!, he goes for the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding up the bottle) Hey, get a bottle opener!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah opens her mouth, as if about to tell him to leave t champagne alone. She stops herself when she realizes she  wants some champagne too. She quickly scrambles about for a bottle opener while Jua unwraps the bottle top. Sarah opens the dresser drawer with such force that a few hidden contents long forgotten in the back of the drawer  slide forward. Some coins, a paperclip, and a hypodermic needle. She loo down at the needle that lays beside the Gideon Bible and  casually picks the phone back up and punches 0. The phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK
dialogues.text: Ted, bucket of ice in his hand, gets ready to go to room  404. As he crosses the desk, the phone rings. He looks at the board and see room 716's light blinking. He sighs in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah sees Juancho shaking the champagne bottle violently

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shake it! (into phone) Ted? Hi. It's me. Sarah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Who died? No one? Then don't  call me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd tell you that your  cleaning ladies are doing a bum job.  There's all kinds of leftover stuff  around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah picks up the needle and rolls it over in her hand  several times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Needles and things. We're not supposed  to have needles here, are we? I mean,  they don't come with the room, do  they? Send someone up here to clean  this place up right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The champagne bottle explodes all over Juancho. He looks  surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Juancho) I TOLD YOU NOT TO SHAKE IT! (to Ted) I gotta go. My brother just exploded  the champagne all over the room. Oh,  and bring us a couple of toothbrushes.  There's a card in the bathroom that  says you'll bring free toothbrushes  if we ask for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. A frustrated Ted hangs up the phone. He walks briskly to elevator. Sarah and Juancho are pouring themselves champagne. They  turn up the television and drink. Juancho shudders at the taste, but tries to drink as much as Sarah. Sarah clearly doesn't like it, but tries to pretend she d Sarah picks up an instruction card near the phone to see to make room-to-room calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling another room, give me  three numbers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah punches in the room number. The phone rings. She holds the needle up to the light to examine it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Hi. You don't know me, and I  don't know you, but... do you have  any needles? We've got needles here  and I was wondering if they come  with the room or not. Don't have  any? Thanks. Just checking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up. Juancho puts down his champagne glass and searches his  father's coat pocket. He finds a pack of cigarettes and t one out. He puts it in his mouth and pretends to smoke. Sarah checks out the hypodermic needle carefully. She has idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bathroom, Sarah seeks out her mother's lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 716
dialogues.text: Sarah stands atop the chest of drawers and uses the lipst to draw a bull's-eye on one of the hotel art paintings. S writes numbers next to each circle representing points. Juancho is standing at the foot of the bed, cigarette han out of his mouth, as he practices his dart-throwing techn

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing out the  rules) The center is the bull's eye, 100  points, this one's 10 points, this  one's 20 points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHACK! The needle lands an inch from her face in the 20-p slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute. Let me get out  of the way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah, a little tipsy now, grabs the needle and staggers the bed. She hears the key in the doorway and throws the  needle into the curtain to hide it. Ted enters the room, somewhat disheveled from his encount with Sigfried. He has a tray and a new bottle of champagn He puts the champagne bottle into the empty bucket. He sp the original bottle lying on the floor half empty and dri into the carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought you some milk and cookies.  If you want some you have to eat  them now, because you're going to  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to sleep now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents said put you to bed  before midnight. Well, it's before  midnight. Maybe that way you'll leave  me alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those aren't milk and cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were out of cookies, so I brought  you milk and Saltines. Don't complain!  Now hurry up and eat. You're going  to bed right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho bites into a Saltine. Sarah simply examines one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're stale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impatient) Dip 'em in the milk! The milk will  make them soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah gives up and throws the cracker back onto the tray. She's a little drunk. Ted picks up the ruined champagne bottle. Juancho dips his crackers and eats them. He makes a face drops a soggy cracker onto the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No crackers? Okay, fine. Sleepy time.  Now, I don't want you guys wandering  around, so if you need to go to the  restroom, go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They go to the bathroom. Ted sits on the bed. Waits. He sees the painting on the wall but can't figure out wha different about it. The red lipstick blends right into the aesthetic value of the painting. Ted smells something funny. He looks down and sees the so on the bed. He grabs a fork from the tray and uses it to  throw the socks across the room. The kids come back out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about our pajamas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna look nice in case there's  an earthquake, don'tcha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Then stay in those clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kids lie on the bed. Sarah notices a jar of Mentholatum ointment on the dinner tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, this is just some Mentholatum  ointment. Come on, under the covers.  Close your eyes and I'll tell you a  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children close their eyes. Ted opens the jar of the  ointment and sniffs it. Strong stuff by the look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your dad says he doesn't trust  babysitters. I don't blame him. You  know what my babysitter did to me  once? (confiding) I never told my parents, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children lie in the bed, eyes closed, listening inten Ted dips his fingers in the jar of vaporous ointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hated going to sleep. You know,  it's nighttime and you wanna run  around and act crazy. So what my  babysitter did to make sure I'd go  to sleep and not be tempted to get  up, was, she'd take some of this  vapor rub stuff... Can you smell  this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes closed, the kids inhale. They smell the ointment and nod yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she'd just dab a little of  this over each eyelid, so that I  would be sure and keep my eyes closed  all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is spreading the ointment over their eyelids as he sa this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. Now you've got some, too!  Don't open your eyes or it'll burrrn,  burn, burn. The smell helps clear  your sinuses too, so it's doing double  duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens when it's morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you keep your eyes closed all  night, it will wear off by morning.  But DON'T OPEN YOUR EYES BEFORE  THAT...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever open your eyes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Extreme CLOSE-UP on Ted's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children are quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in unison) We can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. You'll do just fine. Sleep  well and I won't tell your parents  about the champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted leaves.

dialogues.speaker: AFTER A MOMENT OF DARKNESS
dialogues.text: After a moment of darkness, the night is disturbed by the loud crashing of fireworks outside the window. Sarah sits up, eyes closed. Her face feels the warmth com from the window and she tilts her head toward it. The light of the fireworks dances its reflections off her face. She inhales deeply... then makes a sour face. She goes fo the bathroom, arms outstretched like a blind girl. She ge to the bathroom, turns on the light, and searches for the sink. She begins to wash the ointment off her eyes very careful She dries her eyes thoroughly and opens them... checks th in the mirror. A little red, but otherwise fine. She goes back into the bedroom, turns on the television a grabs the new champagne bottle. She shakes it violently. Juancho wakes. He turns his head to her. His eyes are sti closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you watching TV?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The champagne bottle explodes. She pours herself a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yep. If you wanna watch too, you  have to go wash your face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho gets up smiling and tries to run to the bathroom. slams into the wall, hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho walks into the bathroom a little slower, more  cautious. Sarah pours herself another glass. She downs the glass an shudders. She smells the bad smell again. Only now she really smell it. She smells her feet. Nothing. She smells the champagne.  Nothing. Juancho enters the room and sits on the bed. Sarah grabs foot and smells it. She drops his foot. Juancho stares blankly at her. Sarah looks down at the mattress. She smells the mattress Juancho looks at her as if she's drunk. Sarah leaps off the bed and turns on the room lights. She takes a huge swig from the champagne bottle, then stalks  toward the mattress. Juancho leaps off the bed as well and stands back. Sarah pulls the mattress off of the bedsprings enough to what is underneath it. Juancho screams. Sarah is too stunned to scream. Stuffed  into the bedsprings is a woman's dead and beaten corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted's phone ringing. Ted looks at the phone as if pondering whether or not to  answer it. He taps his fingers. Finally he answers the ph

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want now, for Christ's  sake! Who died?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (near tears) I don't know, but she's in my bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a dead body in my bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just your brother. Sound  asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, there's a woman's dead body inside  the bed, in the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw the body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. You've got ointment on  your eyes! You can't see shit! Now  go to sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted hangs up the phone. Sarah redials. Ted answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Godammit, go to sleep!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying now) I washed it off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You washed off the ointment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed, drunk) Yeah, didn't you ever think to do  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is quiet on the line. Thinking. Juancho lights up a cigarette for real and takes nervous  puffs. Sarah carries the phone over to Juancho and snatches the  cigarette away from him. She stuffs it in her own mouth a nervously takes a long drag on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (through cigarette) You never tried it, did you? Then  you agree I'm smarter than you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Now you listen to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your ass up here and call the  police, because there's a dead body  in my bed and it smells like shit  and it looks even worse, and if you  don't help us, my dad is gonna lay  you down right next to her, I swear  to fucking God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drinks from her champagne bottle. She's pulling the  mattress back over the corpse again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go, sis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's drunk all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incensed) I'm coming up and if there isn't a  dead body by the time I get there,  I'll make one myself. You!

dialogues.speaker: FRONT DESK
dialogues.text: Ted slams down the phone. As he walks away from the counter, he spots the children' parents driving up to the valet out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted breaks into a sprint and dives into a closing elevato

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 716
dialogues.text: Sarah continues to cover the body with the mattress.

dialogues.speaker: ELEVATOR
dialogues.text: Close on Ted's face as the elevator car races up seven fl

dialogues.speaker: LOBBY
dialogues.text: The Man is carrying his drunk Wife through the lobby. Not happy.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 716
dialogues.text: Ted bursts into the room. He sees the disarray. Ted pushes the champagne out of Sarah's hand, spilling it onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on                        !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees Juancho with the cigarette hanging out of his mou and rips it away from him. The butt goes flying onto the  carpet near the spreading champagne spill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your parents are on their way up and  I'm not taking responsibility for  this mess!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check under the mattress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) For the body, can't you smell it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah grabs the mattress and pulls it off herself. Ted sees the rotting corpse. Vomit spews out of Ted's mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gurgles through vomit- spewing lips) Jesus fucking Christ! What the fuck  is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tears at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) Police, it's an emergency! (pause) Hello, Police, this is the Mon Signor  Hotel, get someone up here right  fucking now, there's a DEAD WHORE  stuffed under the mattress!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears well in Sarah's eyes as she looks at the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call her that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into the phone) I'm dead fucking serious, there's a  dead fucking Whore stuffed in the  bedsprings of the fucking bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop calling her that!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah grabs the hypodermic needle from under the curtain stabs it into Ted's leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FUCK!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sarah steps back, almost tripping over the champagne bott She picks up the bottle and holds it defensively in case tries to retaliate. Ted spins around, now noticing the ne sticking out of his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Juancho lights up another cigarette. The champagne spill has spread to the fallen cigarette bu The carpet bursts into flames around the spill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a key going into the keyhole outside.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM 716
dialogues.text: Ted tries to pull the syringe out of his leg, but yanking makes it break in two, the plunger in his hand, and the n still stuck in his leg. Ted staggers and grabs hold of the dead woman's foot for  support as he steps on the remote control, flipping the T on to the Nudie channel, just as... Man opens the door. Man stands at the door, drunk Wife unconscious on one arm the door knob in the other hand. He's looking mean. Man's POV: focused on the dead woman in the bedsprings. W pan up the dead woman's leg to find Ted holding her foot. pan down Ted's leg to find the hypodermic needle jutting  out... then pan over to the other hand holding the broken syringe plunger. We pan over to the Nudie channel, then down to the fire  blazing behind the children. Pan up to the dripping champ bottle in Sarah's hand, then over to the cigarette hangin out of Juancho's mouth. Juancho tosses his cigarette out his mouth to an area behind him. Another blaze starts  immediately. Man drops his Wife to the floor. In the WIDE SHOT of Ted and the children, we see that the fireworks are bursting big and bright outside the window  behind them. Almost as bright as the flames eating throug the room. Man simply glares at Ted. Finally Man speaks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did they misbehave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted stares blankly at Man (the camera) as the sprinklers  burst on... drenching the room as the picture

dialogues.speaker: DAWN.
dialogues.text: The elevator rides down to the lobby. The doors open and wet, disheveled, and frantic Ted steps out. He staggers across the lobby to the reception desk. He gr the phone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BETTY'S APT--ALMOST DAWN
dialogues.text: The wild New Year's Eve party is winding down. Some Guest are passed out, some are asleep, some are making out, two guys are playing Nintendo, a Girl watches them. The phone RINGS. The Girl, who wears a "Guinness Stout" T-shirt, an the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy New Year!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me speak to Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Party's over, she probably went home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lives there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I haven't seen 'em in a  while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you even know who I'm talking  about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... yeah... yeah... I know 'em,  I know Eddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, not Eddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... yeah... I know Betty too...  Tall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not particularly. She's got curly  red hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no, no, I know, I know.  Japanese girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not Japanese! I just said she  had red hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... yeah... yeah... I know her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then get her on the phone,  it's an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who -- who should I say's calling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell 'em Teddy from work's on the  phone, and it's a major fuckin'  emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotcha, Betty from work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Betty from work, I'm calling  Betty! I'm Teddy. Just say Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ted, I'm Margaret. You sound  down. Has this not been the happiest  of New Year's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigning himself to  talking with Margaret) No Margaret, this hasn't been my  best New Year. This year's starting  off pretty badly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awww, how come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Betty -- the chick whose house  you're at, even though you don't  know her -- leaves me here all by  myself on New Year's Eve. And first  thing right off the bat, I'm fucked  by a coven of witches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oven full of witches fucked you?  Is that like at the circus when they  stick all those clowns in an itty- bitty car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A coven. A coven of witches. Well,  one witch in particular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was she an old hag with a mole, with  hair growing out of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No-no-no, she was... quite beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, admittedly, that was the best  part of the night. It was pretty  fuckin' cool, actually. But it was  still an unnerving way to start off  the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds to me like a pretty great way  to start off the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's just skip over the  witches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Skipping over the witches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, later, in another room, some  crazy sucking maniac sticks a gun in  my face and forces me to play out  some psychosexual drama with his  wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made you have psycho sex with his  wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he didn't make me fuck his wife,  he thought I'd fucked his wife! He  held me at gunpoint with a loaded  gun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kinda gun?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'm not a gun guy. It  was big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like Dirty Harry's gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it have a real long barrel or a  short barrel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, for one thing it's the  difference between a .44 Magnum and  a Magnum .357.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares if it was a .44 or a .392,  it was a fuckin' loaded gun, pointed  at my fuckin' head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margaret takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna skip over this part, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to get Betty on the phone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on. (yelling to the room) Anybody live here named... (to Ted) What's her name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sleepy room stirs. Betty wakes up from the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, whatcha screamin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Betty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm Betty, it's my fuckin'  place, who the fuck are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Margaret (hands her the phone) And this is Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty takes the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the problem? I don't got a  problem, I got fuckin' problems!  Wanna hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yawning, wiping sleep  from her eyes) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, most recently, there's room  716. There's a scary Mexican gangster  dude pokin' his finger in my chest.  There's his hooligan kids snapping  their fingers at me. There's the  putrid rotting corpse of a dead whore  stuffed in the springs of a bed.  There're rooms blazing afire...  There's a needle from God knows where  stuck in my leg, infecting me with  God knows what, and finally, there's  me walking out the fuckin' door right  now! Buenas noches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RINGING SOUND happens that we haven't heard before. Ted head turns toward it. It's the guest board. And the top light, the penthouse, i ringing. It rings where all the others buzzed. Betty can hear it distinctly on her side of the line. The sound fully wakes her up. They start talking Howard Hawks style again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly alert) Is that the penthouse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Chester Rush party, they  want something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, tough titty. They're  just gonna have to wait, 'cause I'm  out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panicking) Now, Ted, wait a minute. I know you're  freaked, I know you're stressed.  You've had a real bad night --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Betty, I've had-a-real-bad-night --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You say there's a dead body in a  room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, this is a hotel, we've  had dead bodies before, it's just  the price of doing business. You  said the hotel was on fire. Is it  still on fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, sprinkler system worked like a  charm. Now, you wanna leave, you've  had enough. Perfectly understandable.  I'll take care of everything else.  The only thing I ask is that you  take care of Chester Rush. Then you  can leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, look --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, he's a very important guest of  this hotel. In fact, he is the most  important guest at the hotel. The  Mon Signor used to be a haven for  movie stars. Through the thirties  and forties, and the first half of  the fifties, more movie stars -- if  you break it down on a night-by-night  basis -- stayed at the Mon Signor  than any other hotel in Hollywood.  Now, we had some hard time in the  eighties, even though we were the  official hotel of Cannon Pictures,  but we're coming back strong in the  nineties. And a movie star clientele  is important to that comeback. If we  can keep stars of his magnitude happy,  we're on our way. So, Ted, just take  care of him, then you can leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don't feel like --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He probably just wants some champagne!  You can do that, can't you? Please  just take care of him, the entire  staff of the Mon Signor is begging  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted crumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But get your ass here pronto.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a good man, Ted. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted hangs up the phone. And picks up the board phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Rush. Sorry for the delay.  How can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator door opens and Ted wheels out his tray into hallway. There's been a bit of an effort to make himself appear a less disheveled than in the last scene. He's only minorly successful in the attempt. His uniform still looks like s his hair looks tousled, and he walks with a limp. He wheels the cart up to the penthouse door and KNOCKS at the door. A woman opens the door, it's Angela from Alex's story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Theodore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up the drink she has in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that crazy husband of yours in  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding, he'll be asleep  till Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind her we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Entrez, entrez.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela steps aside and Ted wheels in the tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The penthouse is huge, far and away the best suite in the house. And standing in the middle of the biggest room in hotel is the hottest, newest comedy star to burst onto th Hollywood scene in nearly a decade: Chester Rush. At this moment in time, he's the king, and he has the swagger of new king. After only one movie, he's pulled the sword out the stone. And the look on his face says, "King's good."  Surrounding him is his entourage. They all look like once upon a time this evening they were dressed sharp; however at this late hour, everybody looks about as disheveled as Ted. One of the lads, Norman, has planted roots in a comfy cha with his leg thrown over the arm and a bottle of Jim Beam his hand. The second guy, Leo, is in the back of the room pacing ba and forth on the telephone. He is completely oblivious to the rest of the room's activity. In Chester's hand is an ever present glass of champagne,  which he constantly spills as he gestures wildly. Around room are the leftovers: pizza boxes, fast-food hamburgers and empty bottles of Cristal Champagne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still sitting) Entrez, entrez, come in, come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wheeling in the tray) Hi, sorry I took so long, but I got  everything you asked for --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Not a problem, my friend Mr.  Bellboy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (closing the door) His name's Theodore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it's not Theodore, (he throws a look at  Angela) It's Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester rises from the couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Ted the Bellboy, as I was saying --  would you care for some champagne?  That's not what I was saying, but  would you care for some champagne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya sure? Cristal. It's the best. I  never liked champagne before I had  Cristal, now I love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chester goes and pours Ted a glass:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- As I was saying, Ted, don't worry  about being late. For our purposes,  promptness is far behind thoroughness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On "thoroughness," he hands Ted the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chin-chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They clink glasses and drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadya say, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not thank you. Whadya say about  the tasty beverage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuckin' good, Ted. It's fuckin' good.  Let's try it again, shall we? So,  Ted, whadya think about the beverage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fuckin' good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your sweet bippy, Ted. It's  fuckin' Cristal, everything else is  piss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman in the chair starts yelling at Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bellboy! Bellboy! Bellboy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted knows he's being laughed at, but not why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Norman) Knock it off, you're making my friend  Ted here uneasy. (to Ted) Pay no attention to Norman here,  Ted, he's just fuckin' wit' ya, that's  all. That's from Quadrophenia. Now  me, myself, when I think of bellboys  I think of -- "bellboy" isn't an  insult, is it? Is there another name  for what you do that I'm ignorant  of? Bellman, bellperson --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bellboy's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. I'm glad they haven't changed  that. There's a friendliness to  "bellboy." As I was saying, Ted,  when Norman thinks of bellboys, he  thinks of Quadrophenia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But me, when I think of bellboys, I think of The Bellboy, with Jerry Lewis. Didja ever see The Bellboy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should, it's one of Jerry's better  movies. He never says a word through  the entire film. A completely silent  performance. How many actors can  pull that off? And he has to go to  France to get respect. That says it  all about America right there. The  minute Jerry Lewis dies, every paper  in this fuckin' country gonna write  articles calling the man a genius.  It's not right. It's not right and  it's not fair. But why should that  surprise anybody? When has America  ever been fair? We might be right  every once in a while, but we're  very rarely fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do you want this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You in a hurry, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he is, but doesn't  want to rush the  movie star) No, not particularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, then stop playing "Beat the  Clock." Now let me introduce you to  everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts his arm around Ted and leads him around the room. Angela crosses frame, drink in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our friend from downstairs you already  seem to be acquainted with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she snuggles up in a big comfy chair:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, me and Theodore go way back.  Don't we, Theodore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The name's Ted, Angela. I only let  people with loaded guns at my head  call me Theodore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela's like you, Ted, a newfound  friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We met at the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted) Have you ever seen Angela in a one- piece?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's somethin' to see. (arm around Ted) The Man sitting in the chair, with  the bottle of Jim Bean in his hand  and the sense of humor, is Norman.  Norman, say hello to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sociable son of a bitch on the  telephone is Leo. And the person on  the other end of the phone is his  lovely wife Ellen. (to Leo) Leo, say hello to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo breaks away from his phone conversation for two secon

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Ted, glad you could make it. (back to phone) What? (pause) What does punctuality have to do  with love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which brings me to me, Chester Rush,  Ted. Pleased to meetcha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester shakes Ted's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I'm sorry I haven't seen  your movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester stops. Ted wonders if he should have said that. Chester walks over to the table and pours himself some mo champagne. When he talks now it's slower and somewhat  distracted. The tone of the scene starts changing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's quite all right, Ted, nothing  to feel sorry about. That's why God  invented video. But you know, Ted, a  lot of people did see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester takes a drink of champagne, a disgusted look cros his face, and he slowly puts it down. His manner gives the room a chill. When he talks, he addresses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who drank out of this bottle last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer. Chester walks over to Ted and fills his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who drank out of this bottle -- not  the other bottles -- this bottle  last?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong, Chester?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He spills the champagne from his glass onto the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fuckin' flat, Norman, that's  what's wrong. The champagne -- the  fuckin' Cristal's fuckin' flat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester improvises a temper tantrum about the flat Crista Everyone looks at him, not knowing what to say. Even Leo  walks over to witness. The whole room is uneasy and a lit frightened. When Chester finishes his tantrum, he turns his attention back to Ted. As he talks to him, he opens up another bott But it's not the rapid-pace delivery Chester has done so  far. It's more troubled and distracted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was saying, Ted, a lot of people  did see it. And not just on video,  either. Leo, what was the final take  on domestic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo is still in the doorway making sure his boy's cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 72.1 million. (worried tone) You okay, champ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (struggling with bottle) I'm cool, so talk to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo turns his attention back to the phone and goes inside the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted) 72.1 million dollars. That's before  video and before foreign, and before  pay-TV and before free TV. We're  talking fuckin' asses in fuckin'  seats. (he pops the cork) Before all that other shit, The Wacky  Detective made 72.1 million dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester walks over to Ted and fills his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my new one, The Dog Catcher,  it's projected to break a hundred. (he clinks Ted's glass  with his) The Dog Catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dog Catcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both drink. The tantrum's over, and Chester's back to his fast-talkin good-natured self.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's stroll over here and see  what goodies you brought us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind me asking what's all  this stuff for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One thing at a time, Ted. I'm not a  frog and you're not a bunny, so let's  not jump ahead. C'mon, Norman, you  should be interested in this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn Skippy! (pause) Tell it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted produces the things they called for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A block of wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester knocks on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why three nails?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's how many Peter Lorre asked  for. Continue, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is completely bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roll of twine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's definitely a roll of twine.  Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bucket of ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Norman) You into it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chester) I'm into it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted) Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A donut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester takes it and eats it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for me. Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And a hatchet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hatchet as sharp as the devil  himself is what I asked for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you be the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted holds the hatchet out for Chester to take. Norman sna it instead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be the judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman touches the end of the blade with his thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whadya think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a sharp motherfucker. Bring  all this bullshit over to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard him, Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted is completely confused and starting to get a little  scared, but he does what he's told. Leo slams down the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe, maybe not, but I don't give a  flyin' fuck either way. I've had it  with that Machiavellian bitch! I'm  too drunk to drive home. I'm sorry  about that, I'm real sorry about  that. I got drunk on New Year's Eve,  cut my fuckin' head off... (noticing Ted at the  bar) What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now return you to The Man from  Rio, already in progress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) Noooo, you're gonna do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys ain't bullshittin', you're  gonna really go for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela is still curled up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After talkin' about it all night,  they better. I wanna see a show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When we do it, you'll have something  to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo walks up to Norman and throws his arm around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are one radical dude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted doesn't know what anybody's talking about, which is j fine with him. He finishes laying out everything on the b and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's everything, so if you  don't need me for anything else,  I'll go back downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so fast, Ted. We ain't quite  done yet. Why don't you take a seat  at the bar, get comfortable, and  have an open mind when we explain  the festivities of the evening to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, guys, you paid for the room.  As long as you don't break up the  furniture, you can do whatever the  fuck you want. And me personally, I  don't care if you break up the  furniture. You don't have to explain  anything to me. Whatever constitutes  a good time as far as you guys are  concerned is your business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's your business, Ted. 'Cause  we want you to take part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take part in what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester, your way of breaking the  news to him gently is scarin' the  shit outta him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the poor guy. Just spit it  out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Little by little everybody has gathered around Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First off, let me say that there's  nothing homosexual about what we're  going to ask you to do. There's  nothing sexual at all about what we  want. But I was thinkin' you might  be thinkin' we want you to do some  sex thing. Pee on us, suck us off,  shit like that. Let me assure you  nothing could be farther from what  we want --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I jump in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you can't jump in here, this is  my story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theodore's been here fifteen minutes  and you've talked about everything  but.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, if you don't like it, you can  get the fuck out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo taps his champagne glass with a tiny spoon, shutting  everybody up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it'll please the court, let me  explain to Ted our intentions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) I second the nomination!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Move the nomination be closed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester takes the hatchet and brings it down on the bar l a hatchet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calmly) Leo, the floor is yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. (to Ted) Ted, did you ever watch the old  "Alfred Hitchcock Show"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (totally bewildered  at this point) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever see the episode The Man  from Rio, with Peter Lorre and Steve  McQueen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you'd remember it all right. In  the show, Peter Lorre makes a bet  that Steve McQueen can't light his  cigarette lighter ten times in a  row. Now if Steve McQueen can light  his cigarette lighter ten times in a  row, he wins Peter Lorre's new car.  If he can't he loses his little  finger. (pause) Norman and Chester just made the  same bet. (pause) Norman's putting up his pinky against  Chester's mint convertible, 1964 red  convertible Chevy Corvelle that he  can light his Zippo ten times in a  row.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause. Ted looks at all of them, taking in the information, befo saying:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that goes without saying, but  that doesn't mean we don't know what  we're doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell ya what I'm doin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman lays an issue of Hot Classic Cars in front of Ted the bar. On the cover is a picture of Chester smiling,  standing next to a beautiful 1964 red convertible Chevy  Corvelle. The headline reads: "Hollywood's Hottest New St Next to America's Hottest Old Car."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I drive a motherfuckin' Honda my  sister sold me. You hear what I'm  sayin'? A little white motherfuckin'  Honda Civic. (he holds up the  magazine) You see this shit?! (reading the magazine) "Hollywood's hottest new star, next  to America's hottest old car." (he hands Ted the  magazine) Now you take a good look at that  machine that this motherfucker over  here is standing next to. That's a  1964 nigger-red, rag-top Chevy  Corvelle. And I love that car more'n  I love hips, lips, and fingertips.  Cut to we sittin' here celebrating,  gettin' high, drinkin' champagne --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Cristal. When you're drinkin'  anything else, you're drinking  champagne. When you're drinkin'  Cristal, you say you're drinkin'  Cristal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- drinkin' Cristal. Watchin' TV.  "Rockin' New Year's Eve." When all  of a sudden we flip on Steve McQueen  and Peter Lorre bein' fuckin' badass.  And I look at this funny motherfucker  over here, and I say, "I'd do that  for the Chevelle."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Chester replies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...Oh, really?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys wouldn't be doin' something  this stupid unless you were drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody breaks into a "here, here" murmur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that pretty much goes without  sayin'. We'd probably chicken out.  But when you're fucked-up, you don't  lie. You tell the fuckin' truth. And  the fuckin' truth is, my lucky Zippo's  gonna win me Chester's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Chester) Why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thrill of the bet. I'm the one with  something to lose here. 'Cause I can  pretty near guarantee that I love my  car more'n Norman loves his pinky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Leo) How 'bout you guys, you're just gonna  sit back and let your friends mutilate  each other?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Life don't get much more  exciting than this. I mean if Norman  was puttin' his dick on the choppin'  block, I'd step in, 'cause, ya know  in the morning, we'd really regret  that. But his pinky? Who gives a  fuck? I mean theoretically, he could  lose that choppin' onions tomorrow.  Life still goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Angela) How 'bout you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Ted) I don't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which brings us to your part in this  little wager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Ted, my old granddaddy used ta  say: "The less a man makes declarative  statements, the less he's apt to  look foolish in retrospect." Now  there're some inherent obstacles in  this undertaking. First of all, I'm  not some sick fuck like Peter Lorre  on that show, travelin' the  countryside collecting fingers. We're  all buddies, here. Nobody wants Norman  to lose his finger. We just wanna  chop it off. So if fate doesn't smile  on ol' Norman, we'll put his finger  on ice and rush 'im to a hospital,  where in all likelihood be able to  sew it back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty percent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Norman's protected. His interests  have been looked after. My interests,  on the other hand, have not. I am as  emotionally attached to my car as  Norman is physically to his finger.  I'm putting up a very expensive piece  of machinery on this wager. Now, if  I lose, I lose, I have no problem  with that. I'm a big boy, I knew  what I was doing. However, if I win,  I wanna win. If Norman lights his  lighter ten times in a row, he's  gonna have no emotional problems  about taking my car keys whatsoever.  But if I win, it's not inconceivable  that Leo or myself, at the last  minute, might not be able to wield  the ax. Which brings us full circle  to you, Ted. Sober Ted. Clear-eyed  Ted. We want you to be the diceman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause as they all look at him. Angela breaks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helluva night, huh, Ted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted abruptly gets up and makes a beeline for the door. Chester whips out a hundred-dollar bill and quickly calls Ted from his position at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, I got a hundred-dollar bill  here with your name on it, whether  you do what we ask or not, just to  sit back down in the chair for one  minute more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted spins in his direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna cut off his finger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you will and maybe you won't,  but that has nothing to do with this  hundred-dollar bill in my hand. You  can tell us all to go fuck off and  walk right out that door. But if you  sit back down and wait sixty seconds  before you do it, you'll be a hundred  dollars richer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted just stands across the room, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted. Take the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, you're gonna do whatever you  want to do. We're just askin' you to  indulge us for another minute more.  And Chester's willin' to pay for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted thinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take your money, and I'll sit  back down. But a minute from now,  I'm gonna walk out the door, and  when I do, there'll be no hard  feelings?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I want you to have a bit more  of an open mind than that, but, yeah,  we'll either convince you or we won't.  No hard feelings. Right, guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody agrees. Ted wearily sits back down. Chester positions himself in front of Ted at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Leo, you be the timekeeper.  Let us know when one minute begins  and when it ends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got it. (he checks his watch) Gentlemen, start your engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester jumps up and down, loosening up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester, who talks fast anyway, starts his pitch. It's Ch who now plays "Beat the Clock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, pay attention here, Ted, I  ain't got much time. Now I'm gonna  make two piles here on the bar. (he takes the hundred- dollar bill and lays  it out on the bar) One pile, (pointing at the  hundred-dollar bill) which is yours. And another pile, (Chester whips out a  money roll fat enough  to choke a horse to  death) which could be yours. (he lays a matching  hundred-dollar bill  on the bar, starting  a second pile) Now, what you have to be aware of is  we're gonna do this bet, one way, (he lays another  hundred on the end  pile) or the other. (he lays another  hundred on the pile) Whether it's you who holds the ax, (he lays another  hundred on the pile) or the desk clerk downstairs, (he lays another  hundred on the pile) or some bum we yank off the street. (he lays another  hundred on the pile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can buy a lot of soup with that  pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Norman) Shhhh, I'm the closer. (to the group) How much is on the bar already? I  lost count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred. Ted, do you know how  long it takes the average American  to count to six hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laying another bill  on the pile) One minute less than it takes to  count to seven hundred. You know,  Ted, a person's life is made up of a  zillion little experiences. (he lays another bill  on the pile) Some, which have no meaning, are  insignificant and you forget them.  And some that stick with you for the  rest of your natural life -- (he lays another bill  on the pile) -- barring Alzheimer's of course.  Now, what we're proposing is so  unusual, so outside the norm, that I  think it would be a pretty good guess  that this will be one of those  experiences that sticks. So, since  you're gonna be stuck remembering  this moment for the rest of your  life, you gotta decide what that  memory will be. (He lays down the  last bill on the  pile) So, are you gonna remember for the  next forty years, give or take a  decade, how you refused a thousand  dollars for one second's worth of  work, or how you made a thousand  dollars for one second's worth of  work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Ted, what's it gonna be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted looks at the pile, then looks up. We dolly into his f

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: We see a quick MONTAGE of horrendous moments from all the other stories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group cheers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But when it's over, no matter what  happens, I get the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you do your part, you can  take the pile, walk out the door,  and not say another word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do it right now, before I change  my mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody gets in their position by the bar. Norman lays left hand on the block of wood with his pinky sticking ou In his right hand is his Zippo lighter, poised and ready strike. Chester hands Ted the meat cleaver. Ted takes it, raises it up above Norman's finger, in posi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfect, perfect, perfect, perfect!  This is great! This is a moment in  time none of us will ever forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody is crowded around the scene, on pins and needle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman, you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted, you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okeydoke. Norman, begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Norman looks hard at the Zippo in his hand. Ted, holding cleaver, stares focused on Norman's pinky. Norman readies himself. Places his thumb on the wheel in the Zippo. Takes a breath. And strikes. It sparks, but doesn't light. Without missing a beat, Ted brings down the cleaver, slic off Norman's pinky. Norman lets out a scream. Ted, in one move, lays down the cleaver, scoops up the mo and walks out the door.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HALLWAY--AFTER DAWN
dialogues.text: CAMERA is positioned at far end of hallway, looking down at the elevator at the other end. Ted walks out of the penthouse in the f.g. In a MEDIUM SH he takes the thousand dollars in his hand, looks at it,  smiles, and sticks it in his pocket. It might've been a b night, but it's been a profitable one. He chuckles at the irony, and, whistling a happy tune, turns his back on the camera and walks down the hall to the elevator. All the while we hear PANDEMONIUM breaking out behind the door. As Ted walks to the elevator, the CREDITS ROLL. He waits the elevator, it arrives, he gets in, the doors close. As CREDITS CONTINUE TO ROLL, we hold for about two beats. then... The door BURSTS open and everybody comes piling out.  Everybody's screaming, yelling different things to one  another. Norman has a bloody towel wrapped around his han he's screaming and crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My finger, my fucking finger!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chester has the bucket of ice with the finger in it. Leo' trying to direct everything. Everybody's in frantic activ except for Angela, who stands back, drinks her drink, and watches the show. They all run down the hall, toward the  elevator. Somebody trips and they all hit the ground. The bucket of ice with the finger goes spilling. They run aro like crazy, looking for the finger and picking up ice cub Norman lies on the floor and screams. They pick it all up get to the elevator, and push the button. When it arrives, they all dive in except for Angela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm gonna call it a night  and go back to my room. It's been  fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors close on the screaming maniacs. Angela walks through a door marked "Stairway."

dialogues.speaker: MEDIUM STAIRWAY DOOR
dialogues.text: CREDIT ROLL continues Angela comes through the door; we  STEADICAM in front of her as she walks the halls, looking for her room. She finds it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela sticks her key in the door, then stops when she se something approaching. The look on her face combines stra awe and mild shock. Almost floating ethereally, a mysterious Blond Bombshell, wearing Diana's see-through negligee and slippers, armed  with Elspeth's sword slung over her shoulder, wanders tow her. She is in a daze, perhaps lost or drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay, lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bombshell looks up at her dizzily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said -- you looking for someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disoriented) Uhhh... yes... my husband... I think.  Have you seen him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Angela and the girl have a strange moment as they connect through the eyes. Having had enough emotional intensity tonight, Angela bre their eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lady, I haven't seen anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diana quietly says, "Ohhh," as she drifts on down the hal in a daze. Angela puts her hand to her temples before ope her hotel door. She does a double-take on the hallway --  empty. She pauses a beat, then walks into her room. After the do closes, we hear Sigfried on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the hell have you been?
